text: is an underwater volcano (seamount) of the Hawaiian–Emperor seamount chain in the Pacific Ocean.Tarduno, John A. et al. "The Emperor Seamounts: southward motion of the Hawaiian hotspot plume in Earth's mantle," Science, 22 August 2003, pp. 1064-1069 DOI:10.1126/science.1086442; retrieved 2012-6-14. Ōjin is an extinct volcano.Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute, "Life-cycle of Hawaiian hot spot volcanoes" ; retrieved 2012-6-14. The seamount is also known as the "Ōjin Guyot" because it has a flat top.Guyots are flat-topped because they were once above sea level, and were worn down by the sea. This undersea geologic feature is also called a "guyot" or "tablemount".Geographic.org, "Ōjin Guyot"; retrieved 2012-6-10. This seabed mountain is named after Emperor Ōjin of Japan. The last eruption from Ōjin seamount was 55 million years ago.VolcanoLive.com, "Ojin Seamount"; retrieved 2012-6-10. ==Related pages== * Submarine volcano * Active volcano * Dormant volcano ==References== ==Other websites== * Seamount Biogeosciences Network, database Category:Seamounts Category:Pacific Ocean Category:Volcanoes of Oceania
title: Ōjin Seamount
